newsitem.title: USA: NASA launch site director to retire.
newsitem.headline: NASA launch site director to retire.

text.p: Kennedy Space Centre director Jay Honeycutt announced Tuesday he would leave the National Aeronautics and Space Administration early next year.

Honeycutt, who played an important role in NASA's effort to privatise the day-to-day running of the shuttle programme, said it had always been his intention to retire after two years as director of the Florida launch site.
"It doesn't have anything to do with the changes that are going on, it's just time for me to go do something different," he said.

In late September NASA signed a $7 billion contract with United Space Alliance, a joint venture of Lockheed Martin and Rockwell International, starting the transition to a single private contractor for shuttle launch preparations.
Honeycutt said the greatest challenge facing his successor would be to make the privatisation a success.
He rejected claims by some space centre employees and outside groups that privatisation would threaten shuttle flight safety.
"I think we are as safe today as we have ever been," he said. "We continue to get safer by the day as we learn more about the hardware and how to handle it."
Honeycutt, who has worked in the space programme since 1960, has overseen 13 successful shuttle launches as director of the Florida spaceport.
